Best Practice for Regulatory Framework and Use of 
Credit Rating Information of Domestic Credit Rating 
Agencies in South Asia  
(Financed by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility)

members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  South Asia’s financial markets are among the least integrated. Domestic credit rating 
agencies (DCRAs)—there are nine of these in Bangladesh, India, and Sri Lanka,1  and financial 
sector  regulators  in  Bhutan,  the  Maldives,  and  Nepal  have  begun  to  prepare  for  the 
establishment of DCRAs—have a vital role in developing South Asia’s financial and capital 
markets and facilitating the integration of its financial markets. The Basel II Accord has spurred 
proposals for improvements in the prudential regulation and supervision of DCRAs in view of the 
complex credit risk involved in structured financial products, especially after the global financial 
crisis that began in 2008. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has supported DCRAs with 
equity investments since 1987.2 This time, with the proposed technical assistance3 (TA), ADB 
seeks to help build robust financial systems in South Asia through more effective use of credit 
rating information and a prudential regulatory framework for DCRAs. The sharing of information 
on  each  country’s  DCRA  policies,  regulations,  and  issues  will  strengthen  financial  sector 
cooperation and integration and make South Asian DCRAs more credible and visible. The TA 
framework is in Appendix 1.  
II.  ISSUES 
2.  DCRAs  promote  a  credit  culture,  increase  transparency,  and  reduce  information 
asymmetry between lenders and investors, thus enabling investors to make informed decisions. 
The sharing of credit information levels the playing field among market participants and fosters 
competition in the financial system. Credit reporting4 makes a debtor’s quality much  more 
transparent. Good borrowers are rewarded, and it becomes more costly to default on obligations.  
 
3.  DCRAs  build  information  frameworks  critical  to  the  efficiency  of  financial  markets. 
Investors  can  optimize  their  risk–return  profiles,  monitor  their  portfolios  through  regular 
surveillance and credit rating adjustments, and have timely information for trading and risk 
management. Issuers can assess their loan risk and raise funds under given market conditions, 
and are encouraged to conform to prudential and best corporate practices. Other financial 
intermediaries (such as commercial banks) can better assess risk on behalf of clients. Financial 
regulators are able to exercise more efficient prudential regulation and supervision. 
 
4.  The DCRAs now operating in Bangladesh, India, and Sri Lanka are supervised by 
security regulators. These countries differ from one another in the ownership, size of operations, 
and business focus of their DCRAs, as well as in the penetration and use of credit rating 
information  in  their  financial  markets  and  regulations.  But  Basel  II  has  underscored  the 
significance of DCRAs in external credit assessment. Under the accord commercial banks must 
                                                 
1  These  are  (i)  Credit  Rating  Agency  of  Bangladesh  (CRAB),  (ii)  Credit  Rating  Information  and  Services 
(Bangladesh), (iii) Brickwork Ratings(India), (iv) Credit Analysis & Research (CARE) (India), (v) CRISIL (India), (vi) 
Investment Information and Credit Rating Agency of India (ICRA), (vii) Fitch Ratings India, (viii) Fitch Ratings 
Lanka (Sri Lanka), and (ix) RAM Ratings (Lanka) (Sri Lanka). In India, there are other credit rating information 
companies using a name of credit rating agency but they are not under the registration of Securities Exchange 
Board of India.  Those are Dun & Bradstreet, SMERA, ONICRA, and Micro-Credit ratings International.    
2  An equity investment of Rs0.6 million ($0.45 million) was made in CRISIL (India) in 1987, RM0.49 million ($0.19 
million) in RAM (Malaysia) in 1990, and B5 million ($0.2 million) in TRIS Rating (Thailand) in 1993.  
3  This TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 22 February 2010.  
4  More accurate and transparent financial statements, based on International Financial Reporting Standards, can 
help reduce information asymmetries between debtors and creditors.

2   
rate their loan assets independently to calculate risk weight and determine capital adequacy. 
The fact that many of these banks still do not have internal credit rating systems heightens their 
need for the credit rating information from DCRAs.  
 
5.  The global financial crisis that began in 2008 showed the importance of monitoring the 
methods and practices used by credit rating agencies in assessing debt obligation and debt 
instruments. Financial regulators in advanced economies have made efforts to deal with credit 
rating inadequacies or weaknesses. In emerging economies, such as those in South Asia, the 
prudential regulation and supervision of DCRAs is no less critical to the transparency and 
efficiency of debt instruments. DCRAs are deemed to have a better understanding of the 
domestic sovereign environment and local companies because they have more access to local 
information than their global counterparts. But DCRA ratings—their transparency, accuracy, 
autonomy, and quality—are still a concern to investors. In South Asia, while the code of conduct 
for  credit  rating  agencies  of  the  International  Organization  of  Securities  Commissions  is 
recognized as common practice, each regulator has its own regulatory principles, compliance 
framework, and enforcement mechanism for DCRAs.5  The status of each country’s regulatory 
framework for DCRAs must therefore be examined, and best practices in compliance and 
enforcement determined on the basis of dialogue among country regulators and DCRAs.  
 
6.  In Bhutan, the Maldives, and Nepal, the banking sector dominates the provision of funds 
for private sector development. The capital markets are still nascent, with a limited numbers of 
companies  listed  on  the  stock  exchanges  and  negligible  trading  of  public  bonds  in  the 
secondary markets. No DCRAs are operating. But there is growing demand for corporate bonds 
and an increasing need to streamline public debt issues and market rules. The central banks in 
these  countries  plan  to  introduce  risk-based  supervision  under  Basel  II,  which  involves 
calculating capital adequacy by linking risk to cost of capital. Credit information bureaus have 
been established to store data on the interest payment and repayment of loans by borrowers.6 
At a time when the monetary and security authorities are preparing for the framework for 
establishing a credit rating agency and the provision of credit rating information to the financial 
markets, a study to identify areas where the information could be effectively used would be 
beneficial.7 
 
7.  DCRAs are a key part of resource mobilization. They support private sector development 
by  giving  small-  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (SMEs)  better  access  to  finance  and  by 
promoting infrastructure development through more efficient flow of information. A vibrant SME 
sector attracts investments and creates jobs, thereby lessening the impact of the economic 
slowdown in South Asia. But since the SME sector is largely informal and has no organized 
information on industries, market shares, competition dynamics, or management track record, 
SME creditworthiness must be assessed with tools and methods that are different from those 
used  for  large  corporations.  DCRAs,  by  virtue  of  their  credit  rating  skills  based  on  vast 
experience with country-specific data, have helped expand financial services to underserved 
                                                 
5  To this end, ADB prepared a handbook on international best practice in credit rating in December 2008. ADB 2006. 
Technical Assistance for Capacity Building and Regional Cooperation of Selected Credit Rating Agencies in Asia. 
Manila (TA 6372-REG).  
6  Credit information bureaus created by the central banks operate in all the South Asian countries.  
7  Besides its use in rating bond issues in local currency, the credit rating  information or expertise of a credit rating 
agency  can be used in rating initial public offerings, security receipts, SMEs, corporate governance, mutual funds, 
financial facilities, and insurance companies.

3
segments of the SME sector.8 This will allow risk-based pricing in lending to the sector and thus 
unlock capital in the banks for increased lending to the SMEs. SME credit rating by DCRAs (i) is 
conducive to more efficient decision making and better credit terms from banks because of the 
independent and third-party analysis of the credit quality of the borrower; (ii) facilitates the 
expansion of SMEs by increasing their credibility among bankers, customers, and business 
associates; and (iii) sets benchmarks in credit rating reports for SME credit or lending spread.  
 
8.  In public–private partnership (PPP) infrastructure financing, the risk components and the 
methods of assessing a project company differ from the risks and assessment methods usually 
associated with corporate lending.9 A separate evaluation framework may therefore be needed. 
Ratings by DCRAs offer key advantages derived from their (i) knowledge of and information on 
the government’s policy of pricing flexibility and willingness to intervene in the infrastructure 
sector; (ii) understanding of economic management risk to the state and local governments; 
(iii) dissemination  of  project  company  risk,  which  would  expedite  decisions  by  participating 
financial institutions and investors; and (iv) facilitation of bond issues for PPP infrastructure 
projects. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA will contribute to the development of efficient national and regional financial 
systems with expanding volume and reach in South Asia. Its outcome will be the development 
of national and regional financial markets through increased transparency, accuracy, autonomy, 
and quality of credit rating information provided by DCRAs in the region, as well as more 
effective use of the savings pool to meet the growing financing needs, especially of SME and 
PPP infrastructure projects.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will have five parts: 
(i)  The conduct of country studies in Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, 
and Sri Lanka, covering each country’s (a) regulatory framework (current and 
potential significance of DCRAs, role of the credit information bureau, regulation 
and  supervision,  enforcement,  governance  issues)  and  recommended  best 
practice;10 (b) use  of  credit  rating  information  in  SME  financing  (financing 
                                                 
8  The National Small Industries Corporation (NSIC), the nodal agency for the development of small-scale industry 
(SSI) in India, provides subsidies to entities in the industry to allow them to get a credit rating from credit rating 
agencies or credit rating information companies impaneled with it, such as CRISIL, ICRA, CARE, Fitch, Dun & 
Bradstreet, SMERA, and ONICRA. A circular from the Reserve Bank of India has urged banks to consider the 
NSIC scheme. Although commercial banks are not required to give concessions to better-rated entities under the 
NSIC scheme, banks generally give some benefits, especially to those with a higher rating. The number of SSI 
entities rated under the NSIC scheme now total 16,000-–17,000. 
9  The risks in PPP infrastructure financing typically pertain to (i) project construction risk, (ii) project implementation 
risk, (iii) bidders’ risk, and (iv) subcontractors’ risk. The documents used in due diligence are (i) engineering, 
procurement, and construction contracts; (ii) concession agreements; and (iii) fuel supply and power purchase 
agreements.  
10 The handbook on international best practice in credit rating in December 2008 prepared under ADB regional TA 
will be used in the country studies (footnote 5).

4   
framework, methods, government support, constraints, required conditions, and a 
case study) and policy recommendations; and (c) use of credit rating information 
in PPP infrastructure financing (framework, methods, and government support, 
constraints, required conditions, and a case study) and policy recommendations. 
The country study on India will provide a useful and valuable reference to other 
South Asian countries in view of India’s advanced regulatory framework and 
innovative use of credit rating information, and the variety of products of its 
DCRAs, as indicated in recent research reports.11 
(ii)  On the basis of the country studies, the development of a model framework for 
the region for (a) the regulation and supervision of DCRAs, (b) the use of credit 
rating information in SME financing, and (c) the use of credit rating information in 
PPP infrastructure financing. 
(iii)  The preparation of books and manuals on credit rating methods for (a) SMEs, 
and (b) PPP infrastructure projects. 
(iv)  The conduct of a South Asia regional forum. 
(v)  The conduct of a workshop in Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, and 
Sri Lanka.  
 
11.  The regional forum and the country workshops will be held to disseminate the outputs of 
the  TA  and  to  discuss  current  DCRA  issues  with  regulators  (central  banks  and  securities 
regulators) and with the DCRAs themselves.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $550,000.  It  will  be  financed  with  a  grant  from  the 
Investment  Climate  Facilitation  Fund 12  under  the  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration 
Financing  Partnership  Facility,  to  be  administered  by  ADB.  This  amount  includes  the 
remuneration, travel expenses, and per diems of the international and national consultants. It 
also  covers  the  cost  of  the  training  workshops  and  best-practice  dialogues  (including  the 
honoraria and travel expenses of resource persons); travel expenses, hotel accommodation, 
and subsistence allowances of the participants; and other training expenses such as payment 
for the venues and training materials. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB will be the executing agency. The South Asia Financial Sector, Public Management 
and Trade Division, will implement the TA in coordination with the concerned agencies in each 
country. ADB will also collaborate with the Association of Credit Rating Agencies in Asia in 
disseminating the TA outputs and coordinating the regional forum.  
 
14.  The TA will require about 6 person-months of international consulting services, to be 
provided by resource persons (1 person-month) and by specialists in credit rating agencies 
(2.5 person-months), credit rating agency regulation (0.5 person-month), credit rating for SME 
financing (1 person-month), and credit rating for PPP infrastructure financing (1 person-month).

National consulting services13 (18.5 person-months) will be provided by specialists in credit 
rating  agency  regulation  (5.0  person-months),  credit  rating  for  SME  financing 
(5.5 person-months), and credit rating for PPP infrastructure financing (5.5 person-months), as 
well as a workshop coordination consultant (2.5 person-months).14 The TA will be implemented 
over 12 months, from April 2010 to April 2011. All consultants and resource persons will be 
selected using the biodata technical proposal. The consultants will be recruited in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The 
consultants will be hired individually because the specialized independent studies in the South 
Asia  countries  require  greater  flexibility  in  sourcing  a  broader  range  of  specialists.  The 
disbursements  under  the  TA  will  conform  to  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook.15 The funds under the TA shall be expended only in ADB member countries. No 
activities financed under the TA may be held in each country unless ADB receives a no-
objection letter from each government. A non-objection letter has been under request to each 
government. The outputs of the TA will be disseminated at the regional forum, the country 
workshops, and the website of the South Asia Department. The scope of work and outline terms 
of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3.  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $550,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Financing Partnership Facility for Best Practice for Regulatory Framework and Use 
of Credit Rating Information of Domestic Credit Rating Agencies in South Asia, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

country workshop is to be held.

Appendix 3  9
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.   International Consultants 
  1.  Resource Persons (1 person-month) 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of resource persons (for a total of 
about 1 person-month) who are experts in credit rating regulations, credit rating services, small-
and medium-sized enterprise (SME) financing, public-private partnership (PPP) infrastructure 
financing,  and  debt  market  development,  to  discuss  best  practices  and  other  matters  as 
required at the proposed South Asia regional forum and country workshops. The resource 
persons will have the following responsibilities: 
(i)   Suggest the design of and develop the forum, workshops, or best practices as 
required, and prepare detailed outlines. 
(ii)   Collate and prepare materials for the participants as required. 
(iii)   Deliver a presentation or address at the forum. 
(iv)  Assist in preparing a report after the forum on remaining issues and suggestions 
for possible follow-up activities.  
2.   Credit Rating Agency Specialist (2.5 person-months) 
2.  The specialist will serve as anchor for the technical aspects and as program manager in 
the proposed areas of the TA. The specialist will have extensive skills and experience in credit 
rating regulations, rating methodology, and the business practices of credit rating agencies. He 
or she will monitor and review the quality of the study products developed to answer the needs 
identified in the region. The tasks of the specialist will include, but will not be limited to, the 
following: 
(i)  Monitor and suggest outputs for the country studies to be conducted by the 
individual consultants. 
(ii)  Suggest necessary components and an outline format for the country study and 
knowledge report on credit rating methods for (a) SME financing, and (b) PPP 
infrastructure financing.  
(iii)  Review the outputs and recommendations of each country study and provide 
comments to ensure the quality of research. 
(iv)  Prepare the regional best-practice report on a model framework for (a) regulating 
and supervising DCRAs, (b) using credit rating information in SME financing, and 
(c) using credit rating information in PPP infrastructure financing, by compiling 
and summarizing the country studies. 
(v)  Prepare the proposals of the forum, taking into consideration the regulators’ 
insights and the business practices of DCRAs in Asia.  
(vi)  Support the organization of the forum and other seminars and workshops, as 
required, and assist in their conduct. 
(vii)  Prepare  a  report  on  the  progress  of  the  entire  TA  project,  and  prepare 
presentations to be made to ADB.  
(viii)  Coordinate various activities for the successful completion of the TA project. 
(ix)  Undertake other tasks determined jointly with ADB staff members to manage the 
TA project.

10  Appendix 3 
 
  3.   Credit Rating Agency Regulatory Specialist (0.5 person-month) 
3.  The specialist will have experience in and knowledge of the regulatory issues pertaining 
to credit rating agencies such as International Organization of Securities Commissions practices 
and Basel II guidelines, and the business practices of rating agencies. Work experience in 
regulatory bodies for credit rating agencies or in credit rating agencies is desirable. The tasks of 
this specialist will be as follows: 
(i)  Review the outputs and recommendations of each country study and provide 
comments to ensure the quality of research. 
(ii)  Collaborate on the preparation of the regional best-practice report on a model 
framework for the regulation and supervision of DCRAs. Each country study will 
be compiled and summarized. 
(iii)  Collaborate  on  the  preparation  of  the  proposals  of  the  forum,  taking  into 
consideration the regulators’ insights and the business practices of DCRAs in 
Asia.  
(iv)  Prepare a presentation for an ad hoc forum among rating agency regulators and 
DCRAs in South Asia, and support its organization as required. 
4.   Credit Rating Methodology Specialist SME Financing (1 person-month)  
4.  The specialists must have sufficient experience and expertise in, and knowledge of, 
credit rating methods in SME financing. In coordination with the credit rating agency specialist, 
the specialists will prepare knowledge reports on credit rating methods for SME financing, to be 
used as a handbook of credit rating information and credit risk components of SME. 
5.  Credit  Rating  Methodology  Specialist,  PPP  Infrastructure  Financing  (1 
person-month) 
5.  The specialists must have sufficient experience and expertise in, and knowledge of, 
credit rating methods in PPP infrastructure financing. In coordination with the credit rating 
agency specialist, the specialists will prepare knowledge reports on credit rating methods for 
PPP infrastructure financing, to be used as a handbook of credit rating information and credit 
risk components of PPP infrastructure financing.

DCRAs in the financial sector. The analysis will cover

(d)  the function of credit ratings in the capital market, especially in bond 
market development; 
(e)  potential  uses  for  credit  ratings  outside  the  capital  market,  and  the 
direction of new business expansion by DCRAs; and 
(f)  credit rating fees, and the sustainability of the DCRA business model.  
(ii)  Identify  the  existing  and  potential  regulatory  framework  for  DCRAs  and  the 
enforcement  mechanism  (the  analysis  will  be  based  on  the  handbook  on 
international best practice in credit rating prepared by ADB in December 2008).2 
(iii)  Identify  the  existing  operational  and  regulatory  framework  for  the  credit 
information bureau and define how this differs from the framework for DCRAs. 
(iv)  Define the current and potential governance issues related to DCRAs and global 
credit rating agencies, and identify the status of compliance by each DCRA with 
the proposed best practices. 
(v)  Suggest a model regulatory framework for securing the prudential role of DCRAs 
and the effective use of credit ratings in the financial market. 
(vi)  Analyze the requirements for implementing the model regulatory framework.  
2.  SME Financing Rating Specialists (5.5 person-months; six specialists, one for 
each country study)3 
7.  The specialists will have sufficient experience in and knowledge of the SME sector, 
credit rating information, and credit rating agency activities in each South Asian country. Their 
tasks will be as follows: 
(i)  Identify the framework for SME financing, including the government’s definition of 
“SME” and the central bank’s policy terminology, as well as relevant rules and 
guidelines for promoting SME financing.  
(ii)  Identify the current methods of SME financing by commercial banks, specialized 
banks  for  SME  financing,  finance  companies,  leasing  companies,  factoring 
companies, and others.  
(iii)  Provide statistical data on fund providers in SME financing, and identify the 
significance of these fund providers.  
(iv)  Provide an overview of the support from the government and public organizations 
for SME financing. 
(v)  Analyze the constraints on SME financing. 
(vi)  Suggest ways of reducing the constraints on SME financing, and the role of 
credit ratings in this regard. 
(vii)  Suggest the required environment for the effective use of credit ratings in SME 
financing. 
(viii)  Make preliminary policy and business recommendations. 
                                                 
2  ADB 2006. Technical Assistance for Capacity Building and Regional Cooperation of Selected Credit Rating 
Agencies in Asia. Manila (TA 6372-REG).  
3  Bangladesh  (1.0  person-month),  Bhutan  (0.5  person-month),  India  (1.5  person-months),  Maldives 
(0.5 person-month), Nepal (1.0 person-month), and Sri Lanka (1.0 person-month).

12  Appendix 3 
 
(ix)  Conduct a case study.  
3.  PPP  Infrastructure  Financing  Rating  Specialists  (5.5  person-months;  six 
specialists, one for each country study)4 
7.  The specialists will have sufficient experience in and knowledge of PPP infrastructure 
financing, credit rating information, and credit rating agency activities in each South Asian 
country. Their tasks will be as follows: 
(i)  Identify  the  framework  for  PPP  infrastructure  financing,  including  the 
government’s definition of such financing, the central bank’s policy terminology, 
and the rules and guidelines for promoting PPP infrastructure financing.  
(ii)  Identify the current PPP infrastructure financing methods of commercial banks, 
specialized banks, finance companies, and others.  
(iii)  Provide statistical data on fund providers in PPP infrastructure financing, and 
identify the significance of these fund providers.  
(iv)  Provide an overview of the support from government and public organizations for 
PPP infrastructure financing.  
(v)  Analyze the constraints on PPP infrastructure financing. 
(vi)  Suggest possible measures for reducing the constraints on PPP infrastructure 
financing, and the role of credit ratings in this regard. 
(vii)  Suggest the required environment for the effective use of credit ratings for PPP 
infrastructure financing. 
(viii)  Prepare preliminary policy and business recommendations. 
(ix)  Conduct a case study.  
4.   Workshop Coordination Consultant (2.5 person-months) 
8.  The consultant will provide logistic support to the international and national consultants 
to  enable  them  to  complete  their  tasks,  especially  with  respect  to  report  preparation,  the 
regional forum, and the country workshops.  
 
                                                 
4  Bangladesh  (1.0  person-month),  Bhutan  (0.5  person-month),  India  (1.5  person-months),  Maldives 
(0.5 person-month), Nepal (1.0 person-month), and Sri Lanka (1.0 person-month).

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—policy and advisory technical assistance (R-PATA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Finance (finance sector development, money and capital markets, 
small- and medium-sized enterprise finance and leasing)  
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency and enabling 
business environment), private sector development (private sector 
investment), regional cooperation and integration (money and
